definition: to dress (troops)/to line up (to arrange in a straight line)
exactly/in good order/whole/complete/entire/in order/orderly/to repair/to mend/to renovate/(coll.) to fix sb/to give sb a hard time/to mess with sb

sentences.english: The controls line up so that they can be read like an English sentence.
sentences.chinese: 控件整隊排列，使它們讀起來像一個英語句子。

sentences.english: A whole gang of builders is there tonight.
sentences.chinese: 今晚整隊建築工人都在那兒了。

sentences.english: Just then, a whole flight of bombers zoomed over the house.
sentences.chinese: 就在這時，一整隊轟炸機從房子上空呼嘯而過。

sentences.english: From now on just keep passing the ball and play together as a team.
sentences.chinese: 從現在起，就不停地傳球，如整隊那樣一起打球。

sentences.english: Troops line up at one of the gates to the Kremlin.
sentences.chinese: 士兵們在通往克里姆林宮的一個大門前整隊。

sentences.english: There's no food for us to eat , you took so long with rows.
sentences.chinese: 因爲你花了太多時間整隊，所有已經沒有東西可吃了。

sentences.english: The New York Yankees are a team possessed.
sentences.chinese: 洋基隊現在整隊都像著了魔。

sentences.english: The whole team was in the doghouse for they lost the game.
sentences.chinese: 由於輸掉比賽，整隊都埳入困境。

sentences.english: He was marshalling the troops and organising his teammates into a solid unit.
sentences.chinese: 他正在整隊，將他的隊友組成一個堅固的整體。

sentences.english: The game was over and the players trooped home.
sentences.chinese: 比賽結束了，運動員整隊回家。

sentences.english: This makes him return to, we very whole brigade is blunt pass by.
sentences.chinese: 這就讓他回去了，我們好整隊衝過去。

sentences.english: The children had to form up into lines before being allowed into school.
sentences.chinese: 孩子們得整隊後，才能允許進校。

definition: to charge and break through enemy lines
hissing sound/to hiss (as a sign of displeasure)
cheerleading squad/also written 啦啦隊|啦啦队
Mutan township in Pingtung County 屏東縣|屏东县[Ping2 dong1 Xian4], Taiwan
vehicle/(more specifically) mobility vehicle (mobility scooter, electric wheelchair, Segway etc)
Santimen township in Pingtung County 屏東縣|屏东县[Ping2 dong1 Xian4], Taiwan
to beat sb at their own game (idiom)
lit. single spear and horse (idiom); fig. single-handed/unaccompanied
